thread.title_full: Emails show Neil Gorsuch was a fan of a leading anti-voting rights activist

author: Taylor Link
title: Emails show Neil Gorsuch was a fan of a leading anti-voting rights activist
text:
Tuesday, Mar 21, 2017 6:11 PM UTC Emails show Neil Gorsuch was a fan of a leading anti-voting rights activist President Donald Trump's Supreme Court nominee could be a threat to the voting rights of racial minorities Topics: Donald Trump , Gerrymandering , Hans von Spakovsky , Justice Scalia , Neil Gorsuch , President Trump , racial minorities , Republican Party , Supreme Court , Voting Rights , Politics News , News (Credit: AP Photo/Andrew Harnik, File) 
Neil Gorsuch, President Trump’s nominee for the Supreme Court who is currently going through the ringer in the Senate Judiciary Committee, appears to have ties with an anti-voting rights crusader who popularized misinformation about widespread voter fraud. 
Emails released to the Senate Judiciary Committee indicated that Gorsuch is not only familiar with Hans Von Spakovsky , a senior fellow of the Heritage Foundation known for hyping the voter fraud narrative , but perhaps even a fan of his. 
Back in July 2005, von Spakovsky sent out an email chain announcing a speech he was giving at the Ballot Access and Voting Integrity Conference, which was first reported in The Nation . Gorsuch replied to the email, writing, “Sounds interesting. Glad to see you’re doing this. I may tray [sic] to attend some of it.” 
In a later email from December 2005, Gorsuch was informed that von Spakovsky was in consideration for an opening in the Federal Election Commission. The email conceded that “there will be stories” and that it will be “a little bit of a fight in the press.” Despite these concerns, Gorsuch responded to the email, writing, “Good for Hans!” 
Gorsuch’s time in the Justice Department overlapped with von Spakovsky in 2005, when Gorsuch was the principal deputy to the associate attorney general and von Spakovsky was special counsel to Brad Schlozman, the assistant attorney general for civil rights, The Nation reported. Schlozman and von Spakovsky took control of the Civil Rights Division in the Justice Department and reversed its traditional role in protecting the voting rights of minorities. 
Per The Nation : 
In particular, von Spakovsky manipulated the process to approve Georgia’s strict voter-ID law in 2005, which was among the first of its kind. (I tell this story in great detail in my book Give Us the Ballot.) Von Spakovsky had been an advocate of such laws nationally and in Georgia specifically, where he was from, since the 1990s. “Requiring official picture identification such as a driver’s license with a current address would immediately cut down on a large amount of fraud,” he wrote in The Wall Street Journal in 1995. Two years later, he recommended, “Georgia should require all potential voters to present reliable photo identifications at their polling locations to help prevent impostors from voting.” 
To justify these voting restrictions, von Spakovsky has a history of trying to spread the myth of massive voter fraud. When von Spakovsky worked in the government he was able to change language in a GOP study on voter fraud so that the conclusion was that there was “a great deal of debate on the pervasiveness of fraud.” 
Despite all the facts to the contrary. Taylor Link is a news writer at Salon. You can find him on Twitter at @taylorlink_
